prompt:
Is the person who wrote this in the wrong in the following situation?

"""
WIBTA if I kick my adult ”stepdaughter” out of my house?
New here so if I haven’t understood one of the rules please let me know!

I have a tricky situation I’m going through as of late.  I’m in a long term relationship.  We aren’t technically married, but we live as we are.  After a messy divorce she was never interested in being married again.  We’ve been dating for 8 years now.  I told her that the engagement is the best part so I proposed with both of us understanding that we would never actually get married.  She has an adult daughter who lives with us.  She’s 19. 

My “stepdaughter” and I have never had a good relationship despite my best efforts.  I really gave it everything I could to improve it over the years, but at best she was indifferent to me.  I gave up trying after buying her a car for her 16th birthday and she thanked her mother and didn’t acknowledge me at all even after her mother told her that I alone bought it for her.  

After that I’ve been just waiting her out for the most part.  I’m still kind when I’m around her, but if this is the relationship with me she wants then so be it.  I always assumed that when she turned 18 she would go off to school somewhere.  I was unfortunately wrong.  She instead started working at a salon in town.  She had taken cosmetology in BOCES in high school.  

I thought once she had been working for a bit and had saved enough she would then move out.  Wrong again.  I’ve asked her mother to see what her plans are for the future and if she plans on moving out on her own soon and my wife told me that she just wants to save as much as she can and keep living here.   My fiancé loves having her here, but I’ve been waiting so long to have the house be just my fiancé and I.   

I really feel like I’ve put my time in supporting her daughter and now especially with her having more than enough to move out on her own it’s time to push her out of the nest.  I’m not too concerned with her reaction.   To be blunt I don’t really care how she takes it.   My fiancé will probably be a little upset, but hopefully once the dust clears she will see that it’s for the best.  
"""

Is the author in the wrong? Answer A for Yes (the author is in the wrong) and B for No (the author is not in the wrong). Answer nothing else.

thinking.text:
Okay, let's see. The user is asking whether the author is in the wrong for wanting to kick their adult stepdaughter out. The situation is that the author is in a long-term relationship with their fiancé, who isn't married but live together. The stepdaughter is 19, works at a salon, and has been living with them since she turned 18. The author tried to build a relationship but says it was indifferent, and now they want her to move out.

First, I need to consider the legal aspect. Since the stepdaughter is an adult, she's legally an adult, so the author can't just kick her out without her consent unless there's some legal agreement or lease terms. If she's on the lease, they can't remove her without her agreement or legal process. If she's not on the lease, the author might have more authority if they're the landlord. But it's important to note that in many places, adult children can't be forced to leave unless there's a lease issue or some legal eviction process.

Then there's the ethical side. The author mentions that they tried to build a relationship but it didn't work out. The stepdaughter chose to stay home instead of going to college, which the author had expected. The author feels they've supported her enough. However, the stepdaughter might have different reasons for staying, like financial stability or personal choice. The author's fiancé is okay with her staying, but the author is fed up. 

The question is whether the author is in the wrong. Legally, if the stepdaughter is an adult and not a tenant in a legal sense, maybe the author can set boundaries. But ethically, it's a gray area. The author might have the right to ask her to leave, but the way they're approaching it—being blunt and not caring about her reaction—could be seen as harsh. Also, the stepdaughter might be relying on this home for stability, and the author's decision could impact her negatively. 

However, the author has given her opportunities to move out, and since she's financially independent, it's reasonable for the author to want her to leave. The key points here are the legal rights and the ethical consideration of personal choice versus family dynamics. If the author legally can't force her out without her consent, then maybe they're not in the wrong for asking. But if they try to do it without proper process, that's a different story. The answer might depend on the jurisdiction, but generally, as long as it's done legally, the author isn't in the wrong. However, the ethical angle could argue that the author is being selfish, but others might see it as reasonable for them to want their space after supporting her.
